title: Problem Statement and History
content: Erdős Problem #137 asks whether the product of k ≥ 3 consecutive integers can ever be **powerful**. The related Erdős-Selfridge theorem (1975) proves such products are never perfect powers.
mathContext: A number n is powerful if every prime p | n satisfies p² | n. Equivalently, n = a²b³. The powerful conjecture is weaker than the perfect power result, yet remains OPEN.

title: Powerful Numbers
content: **Powerful(n)** means n ≠ 0 and every prime divisor p satisfies p² | n. Equivalently, all prime exponents in the factorization are ≥ 2.
mathContext: Examples: 1, 4, 8, 9, 16, 25, 27, 32, 36, 72, ... Numbers like 6 = 2 × 3 are NOT powerful (each prime appears exactly once).

title: 1 is Powerful
content: **Vacuously true**: 1 has no prime divisors, so the condition 'every prime p | 1 has p² | 1' holds trivially.
mathContext: This follows from Nat.eq_one_of_dvd_one: if p | 1, then p = 1, contradicting p being prime.

title: Perfect Squares are Powerful
content: If n ≠ 0, then n² is powerful. This uses: if p | n², then p | n (by prime.dvd_of_dvd_pow), so p² | n².
mathContext: More generally, perfect m-th powers are powerful for m ≥ 2. This shows powerful numbers strictly contain perfect powers.

title: Squarefree Numbers > 1 are Not Powerful
content: A **squarefree** number has no repeated prime factors. If n > 1 is squarefree, it has some prime divisor p with p² ∤ n, so it cannot be powerful.
mathContext: The proof uses Mathlib's Squarefree predicate: p * p | n implies IsUnit p. For primes, IsUnit p means p = 1 (contradiction).

title: Consecutive Product Definition
content: **consecutiveProduct n k** computes ∏_{x ∈ (n, n+k]} x = (n+1)(n+2)···(n+k). Uses Finset.Ioc for the half-open interval.
mathContext: Examples: consecutiveProduct 1 2 = 2 × 3 = 6; consecutiveProduct 1 3 = 2 × 3 × 4 = 24. Verified by native_decide.

title: Erdős-Selfridge Theorem (1975)
content: **Axiomatized theorem**: For n ≥ 1 and k ≥ 2, the product (n+1)···(n+k) is NEVER a perfect power mˡ with l ≥ 2.
mathContext: Published in Illinois J. Math. 19(2):292-301, 1975. The proof analyzes prime factorization structure and is highly technical.

title: The Powerful Products Conjecture
content: **ErdosPowerfulConjecture**: For k ≥ 3, the product of k consecutive positive integers is NEVER powerful. This is OPEN but widely believed true.
mathContext: Strictly weaker than Erdős-Selfridge (perfect powers ⊂ powerful numbers). The gap highlights the subtle difference between these properties.

title: 72 = 8 × 9 is Powerful
content: **Verified counterexample** for k = 2: 72 = 2³ × 3² is powerful (both 4 | 72 and 9 | 72). The proof explicitly checks all prime divisors of 72.
mathContext: Key technique: show any prime p | 72 must be 2 or 3 (using Prime.dvd_mul and dvd_prime), then verify p² | 72 by norm_num.

title: k = 2 Case Fails
content: **Demonstrates the k = 2 boundary**: n(n+1) CAN be powerful. We verify consecutiveProduct 7 2 = 8 × 9 = 72 using native_decide, then apply seventy_two_powerful.
mathContext: Infinitely many such n exist (related to Erdős Problem #364). This is why the conjecture requires k ≥ 3.
